comments: a(n) gives also the smallest coefficient for which the multiple M of lcm(1 through p(n)-1) satisfies p(n) divides M + 1. This computes the solution of the puzzle requiring the smallest number such that grouping in 2's, 3's, etc. up to the n-th prime,all leave a remainder of one except the last which leaves no remainder.
example: a(2)=1 because prime(2)=3 and floor(3!/lcm(1,2,3)) mod 3 = 1 mod 3 = 1;a(3)=2 because prime(3)=5 and floor(5!/lcm(1,2,3,4,5)) mod 5 = 2 mod 5 = 2;a(4)=5 because prime(4)=7 and floor(7!/lcm(1,2,3,4,5,6,7)) mod 7 = 12 mod 7 = 5;a(7)=10 because prime(7)=17 and floor(17!/lcm(1,2,...,17)) mod 17 = 29030400 mod 17 = 10.
maple: for n from 2 to 150 do printf(`%d,`, floor(ithprime(n)!/ilcm(i $ i=1..ithprime(n))) mod ithprime(n) ); od:
